content: The Act titled "Small Business Procurement Improvement Act of 2012" aims to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts. The Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns in multiple award contracts to increase participation. The Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns in multiple award contracts by making full use of set-aside programs established in various sections of the Act. The Small Business Act is amended to include small business concerns in multiple award contracts through set-aside programs established in various sections of the Act. Additionally, an Agency Outreach Program will be implemented to increase small business participation in multiple award contracts. The Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy and agencies with 5% procurement through multiple award contracts must implement a program to boost small business participation. This program includes increasing awareness, providing education on bid procedures, and assisting small businesses in getting listed. Section 15(g)(1) of the Small Business Act is amended to require the President to annually establish Government-wide goals for task orders and delivery orders placed against contracts awarded to small business concerns. The President must annually set Government-wide goals for task orders and delivery orders placed against contracts awarded to various small business concerns. SEC. 5. IMPROVEMENTS TO THE SMALL BUSINESS RESERVE. Section 15(j) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the threshold from $100,000 to $200,000 and to include all task or delivery orders placed against multiple award contracts, including those under the Federal Supply Schedule program. The Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of General Services Administration, shall ensure this subsection's applicability. The Administrator, in consultation with the General Services Administration, will issue regulations within 120 days of enactment to ensure correct size standards for task orders under the Federal Supply Schedule program. The Administrator will issue regulations to apply correct size standards to task orders under the Federal Supply Schedule program, ensuring implementation of non-manufacturer rule and subcontracting provisions at the task order level, and displaying correct size information for small businesses on electronic ordering systems. The Administrator of the General Services Administration will ensure that electronic ordering systems display correct size information for small businesses seeking task order set asides. SEC. 6. SMALL BUSINESS REPRESENTATION ON THE FEDERAL ACQUISITION REGULATORY COUNCIL. Section 1302(b)(1) of title 41, United States Code is amended to include the Administrator of the Small Business Administration. In cases of an equal vote among council members, the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy will have the deciding vote. In cases of a tie vote among council members, the Administrator of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy will have the deciding vote.
